pullRequest.body:
This proves the first step of the proof of the Archimedean case of Ostrowski's Theorem, namely that a rational absolute value `f : MulRingNorm ℚ` that is not bounded, i.e. such that, evaluated at an integer `n`, it attains a value greater than one, then `f n` is always greater than one, whenever `1<n`.

```lean
lemma one_lt_of_not_bounded (notbdd : ¬ ∀ (n : ℕ), f n ≤ 1) {n₀ : ℕ} (hn₀ : 1 < n₀) : 1 < f n₀
```

Include also
- preliminary lemmas on limits of functions with natural inputs
- technical lemma on an inequality between an integer and an expression involving MulRingNorm and the number of digits of its expansion in an integer base
- triangle inequality for lists (added in the file RingSeminorm.lean)

#17138 completes the proof of the theorem

Co-authored-by: David Kurniadi Angdinata <dka31@cantab.ac.uk>
Co-authored-by: Fabrizio Barroero <fabrizio.barroero@uniroma3.it>
Co-authored-by: Laura Capuano <laura.capuano@uniroma3.it>
Co-authored-by: Nirvana Coppola <nirvanac93@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: María Inés de Frutos Fernández <maria.defrutos@uam.es>
Co-authored-by: Silvain Rideau-Kikuchi <silvain.rideau-kikuchi@ens.fr>
Co-authored-by: Sam van Gool <vangool@irif.fr>
Co-authored-by: Francesco Veneziano <veneziano@dima.unige.it>

---

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

### PR summary [d4d83120db](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/14442/commits/d4d83120dbc71a01a63b0225190af27ed4be4978)

<details><summary>

#### Import changes for modified files

</summary>

Dependency changes

| File | Base Count | Head Count | Change |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Mathlib.NumberTheory.Ostrowski | 1414 | 1417 | +3 (+0.21%) |


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.NumberTheory.Ostrowski`|3|

</details>

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ mulRingNorm_apply_le_sum_digits`
`+ mulRingNorm_sum_le_sum_mulRingNorm`
`+ one_lt_of_not_bounded`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
What is the status of this PR? It seems to me that you might have forgot to push your commit.

> What is the status of this PR? It seems to me that you might have forgot to push your commit.

sorry forgot to push, you're right

As for @erdOne suggestion to move the "preliminary lemmas": there are some natural folders in Mathlib where they might go but it's unclear to me whether we want to clog the limits section with these.

One solution would be to write a meta-lemma like this one (thanks to @fbarroero):
``theorem aux {l: Filter ℝ} {f : ℝ → ℝ} {g: ℕ → ℝ} (hg: ∀ᶠ n in atTop, g n = f n) (hl : Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop l) : Filter.Tendsto g Filter.atTop l := by sorry``

would that make sense?
I think that is exactly `Filter.Tendsto.congr'`

> I think that is exactly `Filter.Tendsto.congr'`

Thanks! it seems to me that `Filter.Tendsto.cong'` requires the two functions to have the same domain though

I have a more general version of the above theorem `aux` like this
```lean 
theorem aux' {α : Type*} [Nonempty α] [LinearOrder α] {l : Filter ℝ} {f : ℝ → ℝ} {g : α → ℝ}
    {c : α → ℝ} (hc₀ : Monotone c) (hc : ∀ x : ℝ, ∃ a : α, x ≤ c a)
    (hg : ∀ᶠ n in atTop, g n = f (c n)) (hl : Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop l) :
    Filter.Tendsto g Filter.atTop l
```
Would this make it more interesting? This would give limits at infinity for functions with domain $\mathbb{N}$, $\mathbb{Z}$, $\mathbb{Q}$...

As for the late commit a couple of remarks:
- the lemma about natLog vs realLog is now in Mathlib as `Real.natLog_le_logb` so it has been removed here
- the lemmas about the limits are now private (and use the Zulip suggestion that the coercion from Nat to Real tends to atTop along atTop)

This PR still makes some erroneous changes (e.g. incorrectly changing `-/` to `--/`) which need to be fixed before we can consider merging it. 

Usually it's nice to have smaller PRs to review, but how far are we away from the proof of the main theorem which you want here? The lemmas introduced here currently look weird and unmotivated -- I know they're not, but they look like it because the ultimate goal is missing. If you added the full proof how long would the PR be?

> This PR still makes some erroneous changes (e.g. incorrectly changing `-/` to `--/`) which need to be fixed before we can consider merging it.
> 
> Usually it's nice to have smaller PRs to review, but how far are we away from the proof of the main theorem which you want here? The lemmas introduced here currently look weird and unmotivated -- I know they're not, but they look like it because the ultimate goal is missing. If you added the full proof how long would the PR be?

The full proof can now be found in #17138. There are 167 lines in addition to what is in this PR.
Do you need help with merging master?

> Do you need help with merging master?

Maybe, I am trying to solve it myself.. I hope I didn't make a mess.
I let you know if I need help, thanks

> Do you need help with merging master?

Everything should be fine now. Thanks for having offered to help!
Are you sure? There are still 162 commits and 52 participants in this PR.

> Are you sure? There are still 162 commits and 52 participants in this PR.

I am sorry. I don't know what happened earlier. I just wanted to merge master and that's what I thought I was doing in the same way I always do (pull in the master and then `git merge master` in the branch).
I merged master again and the second time it seems it worked just fine.
I guess all these 52 people are going to get automatically subscribed to this PR and I apologise for the spam.
Is there a way to fix this? I would appreciate anyone's help.
I'm going to try something. Please don't touch the branch for a few minutes

Looks like that solved it. Please make sure you have no local changes on branch `amos_ostrowski_arch`, then run `git reset origin/amos_ostrowski_arch --hard`. ⚠️ This will lose all your local changes on this branch ⚠️

> Looks like that solved it. Please make sure you have no local changes on branch `amos_ostrowski_arch`, then run `git reset origin/amos_ostrowski_arch --hard`. ⚠️ This will lose all your local changes on this branch ⚠️

I have done that.
Thank you very much! 
And I apologise again for the mess...
@YaelDillies Thanks for the golfing! It's much cleaner now.

Great, thanks!

maintainer merge
🚀 Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by YaelDillies.

Thanks a lot! Looking forward to the next instalment of the proof of this important and long-awaited result!

bors merge

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11355371773/job/31584562609)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11355371773/job/31584562939)
Can you please merge master? Some lemmas you are using were renamed
`#find_home! nat_log_le_real_log` says that this should go in `Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Log.Base`. Should we move it there or leave it here?
I think all of these "Preliminary lemmas" should have better places to go to.

```suggestion
/-! ## Preliminary lemmas on limits -/
```
Please use this syntax so that this comments will appear in the docs.

Same below.
Done!

```suggestion
lemma mulRingNorm_le_sum_digits (n : ℕ) {m : ℕ} (hm : 1 < m):
```

```suggestion
/-- extends the lemma `tendsto_rpow_div` when the function has natural input --/
```

```suggestion
    (hg : Tendsto g Filter.atTop (nhds l)) : a ≤ l := by
```

```suggestion
private lemma tendsto_root_atTop_nhds_one {C : ℝ} (hC : 0 < C) :
    Tendsto (fun k : ℕ ↦ C ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹) atTop (nhds 1) := by
```

```suggestion
    (fun a ↦ Real.continuousAt_const_rpow hC.ne')) 0 1 (Real.rpow_zero C))
```

```suggestion
private lemma tendsto_nat_rpow_div :
    Tendsto (fun k : ℕ ↦ (k : ℝ) ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹) atTop (nhds 1) := by
```
Are none of those lemmas useful enough to put somewhere in the library?
The domain of these functions is `\N` so it is very specific, possibly too specific to go in the limit section of Mathlib?

```suggestion
  convert_to Tendsto ((fun k : ℝ ↦ k ^ k⁻¹) ∘ Nat.cast) atTop (nhds 1)
```
Please revert all these
Done!
Looks like you didn't actually revert these

```suggestion
      rintro ⟨i, a⟩ hia
```
Why do you need the `id`?
Is there not some boundedness predicate that you can use? Otherwise a not-forall hypothesis looks odd; you might just make it `{n : \N} (hn : 1 < f n)` to match the documentation
We used this to mimick the "boundedness" in the non Archimedean case and make the proof more readable from the math point of view. Given this maybe leaving it like this make sense?

```suggestion
  rcases eq_or_ne n 0 with rfl | h₀
  · simp only [CharP.cast_eq_zero, map_zero, zero_le_one]
```

```suggestion
    have hnlim : Tendsto (fun k : ℕ ↦ (n₀ * (Real.logb n₀ n + 1)) ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹) atTop (nhds 1) :=
      tendsto_root_atTop_nhds_one
        (mul_pos
          (mod_cast (lt_trans zero_lt_one hn₀))
          (add_pos (Real.logb_pos (mod_cast hn₀) (by norm_cast; omega)) Real.zero_lt_one))
```

```suggestion
    exact hnlim.mul tendsto_nat_rpow_div
```
Throughout, you may wish to use the fancy N rather than `nhds`
done!

```suggestion
/-- Triangle inequality for `MulRingNorm` applied to a list. -/
```

Try keeping the import list somewhat alphabetical
```suggestion
import Mathlib.Analysis.SpecialFunctions.Pow.Continuity
import Mathlib.Analysis.Normed.Ring.Seminorm
import Mathlib.NumberTheory.Padics.PadicNorm
```

```suggestion
    (hg : Tendsto g Filter.atTop (𝓝 l)) : a ≤ l := by
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
-/
```

```suggestion
```

```suggestion
    have := Real.logb_pos (mod_cast hn₀) (by norm_cast; omega)) Real.zero_lt_one
    have hnlim : Tendsto (fun k : ℕ ↦ (n₀ * (Real.logb n₀ n + 1)) ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹) atTop (𝓝 1) :=
      tendsto_root_atTop_nhds_one (by positivity)
```
or something like that

We don't indent docstrings
```suggestion
`m + m * f m + m * (f m) ^ 2 + ... + m * (f m) ^ d` where `d` is the number of digits of the
expansion of `n` in base `m`. -/
```

```suggestion
lemma mulRingNorm_apply_le_sum_digits (n : ℕ) {m : ℕ} (hm : 1 < m) :
```

We tend to avoid indenting the main part of the proof
```suggestion
    _ ≤ (L.mapIdx fun i _ ↦ m * (f m) ^ i).sum := ?_
  simp only [hL', List.mapIdx_eq_enum_map, List.map_map]
  apply List.sum_le_sum
  rintro ⟨i, a⟩ hia
  dsimp [Function.uncurry]
  replace hia := List.mem_enumFrom hia
  push_cast
  rw [map_mul, map_pow]
  apply mul_le_mul_of_nonneg_right (le_of_lt (hcoef _))
    (pow_nonneg (apply_nonneg f ↑m) i)
  simp only [zero_le, zero_add, tsub_zero, true_and] at hia
  exact List.mem_iff_get.mpr ⟨⟨i, hia.1⟩, hia.2.symm)
```
I feel like this proof could be made into a nice `calc` block. Mind giving it a go?
Done

```suggestion
    f n = (f n ^ (k : ℝ)) ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹ := by rw [rpow_rpow_inv (by positivity) (by positivity)]
```
is more robust to future changes

Can you avoid meddling inequality steps and rearrangement steps? Here this involves adding a new `_ = ... := ...` line so that the proof here becomes
```suggestion
    _   ≤ ... := by
      gcongr
      exact h_ineq1 (one_le_pow k n h₀.bot_lt)
```
(the point being that the `rw` is gone)
Done. the block now consists of a rearrangement, an inequality, a rearrangement, an inequality and one last rearrangement.

```suggestion
    _ = (n₀ * (logb n₀ n + 1)) ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹ * k ^ (k : ℝ)⁻¹ :=
      mul_rpow (by positivity) (by positivity)
```

```suggestion
      exact h_ineq1 (one_le_pow₀ k n h₀.bot_lt)
```
and please merge a *recent* master! `one_le_pow` is now deprecated

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/Ostrowski): First step of the proof of the Archimedean case of Ostrowski's Theorem
